issues.description: The template's addGuestStudents method signature has an extra boolean parameter (addGuestStudents(int, boolean)) while the problem statement and the solution expect a single-parameter method addGuestStudents(int). This parameter mismatch is structural: students following the template signature will implement a method that does not match the exercise specification or the reference solution, and automated tests (and the UML) will expect the single-parameter signature. This can prevent students from compiling against the expected API and will cause confusion about the required method signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to match the specification and solution: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... }. If input validation is desired in the template, either implement it internally (without changing the public signature) or provide an overloaded private/helper method; do not change the public API from the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a method addGuestStudents(int) (single integer parameter). The solution implementation provides addGuestStudents(int) with a single int parameter as expected. However, the template repository declares addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) (an extra boolean parameter). This signature mismatch (extra parameter) creates a mapping barrier: students reading the exercise will implement/expect addGuestStudents(int) but the template forces a different method shape, causing confusion about the required API and failing to match the intended solution/tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to match the problem statement and solution: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... }. If input validation is desired, implement it internally (or provide an overload) rather than changing the public API expected by the exercise and tests.
